questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about optic neuritis? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: There is no pain on ocular movement.

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Relative afferent pupillary defect is seen.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A relative afferent pupillary defect is a critical clinical sign in diagnosing optic neuritis, highlighting the asymmetric impact on optic nerve function. Understanding and correctly identifying this sign is vital for early and accurate diagnosis and management of optic neuritis.

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral cataracts, patent ductus arteriosus, and sensorineural hearing loss. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
  • ➤ 1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • ➤ It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.
  • ➤ 2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.
  • ➤ 3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: A patient of HIV with low CD4 count presents with the following finding. Which of the following is used in the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ganciclovir

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a case of retinitis, a common ocular manifestation in HIV patients with low CD4 counts.
  • • Retinitis can be caused by various pathogens, but in the context of HIV with a low CD4 count, Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is a significant concern. This condition is typically seen when the CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³. CMV retinitis presents with retinal necrosis and can progress rapidly, leading to blindness if not treated promptly.
  • • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis
  • • CD4 count falls below 100 cells/mm³.
  • • The treatment of choice for CMV retinitis is Ganciclovir, which can be administered intravitreally to deliver the drug directly to the affected site in the eye. Ganciclovir inhibits viral replication by targeting viral DNA polymerase, making it effective against CMV.
  • • intravitreally
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acyclovir : This antiviral is used primarily for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) and Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) infections.
  • • Option A. Acyclovir
  • • Option B. Valacyclovir : This is a prodrug of acyclovir and is also used for HSV and VZV infections.
  • • Option B. Valacyclovir
  • • Option C. Tenofovir : This antiviral is used in the treatment of HIV and Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infections.
  • • Option C. Tenofovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for CMV retinitis in HIV patients with low CD4 counts, administered intravitreally to manage the infection effectively and prevent blindness.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Ocular manifestation of HIV –
  • ➤ Ocular manifestation of HIV –

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. To correct that, he tilts the head on one shoulder. Which nerve palsy is suspected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4th CN palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presenting with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs and tilting the head on one shoulder to correct the vision suggests a 4th cranial nerve (CN) palsy. The 4th cranial nerve, also known as the trochlear nerve, innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • • superior oblique muscle.
  • • The primary actions of the superior oblique muscle include intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.
  • • intorsion,
  • • When there is a palsy of the 4th cranial nerve, the affected eye may have difficulty performing these movements, leading to vertical diplopia. Patients often adopt a compensatory head tilt to align the eyes properly and alleviate the double vision. The head tilt is typically towards the shoulder opposite the affected eye, compensating for the muscle's inability to properly intort and depress the eye.
  • • compensatory head tilt to align the eyes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 3rd CN palsy : This palsy typically presents with ptosis (drooping eyelid) and an eye that is deviated down and out. Patients often lift their chin to see beneath the drooping lid, not to correct vertical diplopia.
  • • Option A. 3rd CN palsy
  • • Option C. 6th CN palsy : The 6th cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the eye. A palsy here would result in horizontal diplopia, not vertical diplopia, and the patient might turn their head to compensate, not tilt it.
  • • Option C. 6th CN palsy
  • • Option D. 7th CN palsy : This nerve controls facial muscles, and its palsy leads to facial muscle weakness or paralysis, not issues related to eye movement or diplopia.
  • • Option D. 7th CN palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 4th cranial nerve palsy (trochlear nerve palsy) leads to vertical diplopia, which patients often compensate for by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder to align the eyes and improve vision.
  • ➤ Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3
  • ➤ Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3
  • ➤ Superior oblique by 4 th CN; Lateral rectus by 6 th CN and Rest all muscle by 3 rd CN
  • ➤ Superior oblique by 4 th CN; Lateral rectus by 6 th CN and Rest all muscle by 3 rd CN

questions.text: A 60-year-old presents with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dacryocystorhinostomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ adults

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: A patient presents with neurological symptoms and Kayser-Fleischer rings. What is the best initial screening test for Wilson's disease? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Serum ceruloplasmin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When Wilson's disease is suspected based on clinical features like KF rings and neurological symptoms, serum ceruloplasmin is the most appropriate initial screening test before proceeding to more invasive confirmatory testing.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problem in his right eye. On examination IOP of his right eye is 50 mmHg and left eye is 16 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows presence of flare cells in anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the right eye. What is the diagnosis of this condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by high intraocular pressure, presence of flare cells in the anterior chamber, and a cataractous lens.

questions.text: After cataract surgery, endophthalmitis developed. How will you prevent post operative endophthalmitis?( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Povidone iodine before surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To prevent postoperative endophthalmitis following cataract surgery, the application of povidone-iodine on the ocular surface before surgery is the standard prophylactic procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following lipid storage disorder presents with Cherry Red Spot in Macula? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tay Sach's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cherry-red spot in the macula is a characteristic finding in several lipid storage disorders, with Tay Sachs disease being the most notable.
  • ➤ The mnemonic "BeE STING" can be helpful in remembering causes of cherry-red spot: Berlin's Edema, Sclerosis, Tay-Sachs, Ischemia (CRAO), Niemann-Pick, and GM1 Gangliosidosis.
  • ➤ mnemonic "BeE STING"

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago following which he had developed genital ulcers. Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the following will be seen on exposure of his pupils to light? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate

options.label: B
options.text: Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.correct_answer: B. Pupils accommodate but do not react
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pupils accommodate but do not react

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by pupils that accommodate but do not react to light, is a hallmark of neurosyphilis. This condition reflects damage to the central nervous system by Treponema pallidum, which affects both the neurological and visual systems.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a painful, bluish-purple nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with severe discomfort that persists despite topical medications. The patient also reports morning stiffness in multiple joints. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Scleritis with Rheumatoid Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scleritis can be distinguished from episcleritis by:
  • ➤ Severe pain not responding to topical therapy Bluish-purple discoloration Need for systemic therapy Strong association with systemic autoimmune diseases Higher risk of vision-threatening complications if untreated
  • ➤ Severe pain not responding to topical therapy
  • ➤ Bluish-purple discoloration
  • ➤ Need for systemic therapy
  • ➤ Strong association with systemic autoimmune diseases
  • ➤ Higher risk of vision-threatening complications if untreated

questions.text: What is the drug used for refraction in a child with squint? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1% Atropine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1% Atropine is the preferred drug for refraction in a child (<7 yr children) with squint, particularly because it is the strongest cycloplegic agent available.
  • • Children often have strong accommodation, which can interfere with accurate refraction, especially in cases of accommodative esotropia. Using a potent cycloplegic like 1% atropine helps to fully relax the accommodation, allowing for precise measurement of refractive errors.
  • • Atropine 1% is typically preferred in ointment form due to its longer duration of action and ease of application. The ointment can be applied to the eyelashes or lower lid, ensuring widespread coverage over the entire eye surface. This is especially useful for children under the age of 7 who require thorough cycloplegia for accurate refraction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tropicamide : This is a short-acting cycloplegic used primarily in adults. It is not strong enough to overcome the strong accommodation seen in children.
  • • Option B. Tropicamide
  • • Option C. Homatropine : Although it has cycloplegic properties, it is less potent than atropine and not the first choice for children with squint.
  • • Option C. Homatropine
  • • Option D. Cyclopentolate : This is another cycloplegic agent used in children, but it is less potent than atropine. It can be used if atropine is not available or in specific cases where a slightly less strong cycloplegic is sufficient.
  • • Option D. Cyclopentolate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1% Atropine is the drug of choice for refraction in children with squint due to its strong cycloplegic effect, ensuring accurate measurement of refractive errors by fully relaxing accommodation.
  • ➤ Mnemonic – ACHT - Order of Potency -
  • ➤ Mnemonic – ACHT
  • ➤ A tropine strongest potency C yclopentolate H omatropine T ropicamide
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ H
  • ➤ T

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye) in a 10-year-old boy is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anisometropic amblyopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A difference in refractive power between the two eyes of more than 2.5 diopters can lead to anisometropic amblyopia, especially if untreated during the critical period of visual development (up to about 7 years of age)

questions.text: Which of the following would be prescribed for simple myopic astigmatism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. -1.00 DC X 180 degree

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction with a cylindrical lens that corrects the myopic meridian, typically specified with the cylinder power and the axis. The correct prescription for simple myopic astigmatism in this case is -1.00 DC X 180 degrees.

questions.text: A 1-week-old child presented with severe jaundice, hemolysis, and dark urine. The child developed cyanosis after consuming fava beans in breast milk. This can be caused due to the deficiency of which enzyme? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency is an X-linked disorder presenting with acute hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress. Early recognition is crucial to prevent triggers and manage acute crises effectively.

questions.text: In which condition is pupillary light reaction absent and accommodation reaction present? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurosyphilis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition described is characteristic of the Argyll Robertson pupil, which is associated with neurosyphilis. In this condition, the pupillary light reflex is absent, meaning the pupils do not constrict in response to light. However, the accommodation reflex, which involves pupil constriction when focusing on a near object, is preserved. This phenomenon is often summarized by the -
  • • Argyll Robertson pupil,
  • • neurosyphilis.
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • Mnemonic "ARP and PRA" (Accommodation Reflex Present and Pupillary Reflex Absent).
  • • The underlying mechanism involves damage to the interneurons in the pretectal area of the midbrain, which affects the light reflex pathway while sparing the accommodation pathway.
  • • The Near triad , consisting of accommodation, convergence, and miosis, remains intact in neurosyphilis, explaining why accommodation is preserved.
  • • Near triad
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome : This condition is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to a disruption in the sympathetic pathways. The pupillary light reaction is not typically absent.
  • • Option B. Horner’s syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis
  • • Option C. Papilledema : This condition involves swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. The pupillary light reaction is usually normal in papilledema.
  • • Option C. Papilledema
  • • swelling of the optic disc
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis : This inflammation of the optic nerve often leads to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil, where the affected eye shows a reduced direct response to light. However, the accommodation reaction is not selectively preserved as described.
  • • Option D. Optic neuritis
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or Marcus Gunn pupil,

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Argyll Robertson pupil, associated with neurosyphilis, presents with absent pupillary light reaction and preserved accommodation reaction, highlighting a distinctive neuro-ophthalmologic sign of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a medical emergency. Rapid recognition and aggressive treatment are essential to prevent serious complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: The parts of a pterygium are head, neck and body.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is characteristic of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bitot spots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitot spots are a characteristic sign of vitamin A deficiency, appearing as dry, foamy patches on the conjunctiva and representing stage X1B of xerophthalmia.

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.
  • ➤ Hyperopia

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of complicated cataracts? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Krukenberg spindle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Krukenberg spindle is a vertical, spindle-shaped deposit of pigment on the posterior surface of the cornea, commonly seen in pigmentary glaucoma. It results from the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris that adhere to the corneal endothelium.

questions.text: A patient presented with sudden, painful diminution of vision, difficulty in vision in light, and circumferential congestion with corneal edema and fixed mid-dilated pupil as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute Congestive Glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute angle-closure glaucoma can be distinguished from other causes of red eye by its characteristic mid-dilated pupil, corneal edema, and severe pain. This represents an ocular emergency requiring immediate treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: What are the yoke muscles for levodepression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) R SO and LIR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The yoke muscles responsible for levodepression (movement of the eyes to the left and downward) are the right superior oblique and the left inferior rectus.

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Floor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

questions.text: Normal commensal conjunctival flora are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Staph. epidermidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora of the conjunctiva. It's crucial to manage this normal flora during eye surgeries to prevent postoperative endophthalmitis. The use of povidone-iodine in the immediate pre-operative period is considered the best practice for preventing endophthalmitis by reducing the population of normal commensal flora on the ocular surface.
  • ➤ The use of povidone-iodine in the immediate pre-operative period is considered the best practice

questions.text: Identify the instrument.( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lim’s forceps are specialized ophthalmic instruments used primarily for corneal suturing, featuring a platform-like tip to gently hold eye tissues during delicate procedures.

questions.text: Local anesthesia used in cataract surgery is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lignocaine 2%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lignocaine 2% is the standard local anesthetic used in cataract surgery due to its rapid onset and appropriate duration of action. However, it's important to note that topical anesthesia using proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.
  • ➤ proparacaine 0.5% is becoming increasingly common in modern cataract surgery techniques.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? ( NEET PG 2021)

questions.text: What is the most common cause of moderate-severe visual impairment according to the National Blindness and Visual Impairment Survey 2015-19? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Untreated cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prevalence of untreated cataracts as a leading cause of moderate-severe visual impairment emphasizes the need for effective public health strategies focusing on eye health screenings and accessible cataract surgery to reduce the burden of preventable blindness and visual impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic presentation of internuclear ophthalmoplegia involves a failure of adduction in the affected eye due to a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. Recognizing this pathway and its role in horizontal eye movement coordination is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the clinical manifestations of INO.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wire Speculum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A wire speculum is a key instrument in ophthalmic surgery, used to keep the eyelids open and provide access to the eye during various procedures. Its characteristic wire-like structure with loops at the ends distinguishes it from other lid manipulation instruments.

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures, hypocalcemia, gum changes, poor wound healing, and lens opacification. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (Twisted PYQ)

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C deficiency can present with diverse manifestations affecting multiple systems, including neurological

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic patient had undergone surgery for cataract. 6 weeks post-operatively, the patient came with inflammation, decreased vision. On further examination, honeycomb appearance of retina is seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystoid macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a diabetic patient presenting with postoperative inflammation and decreased vision featuring a honeycomb appearance of the retina, the likely diagnosis is cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Acute leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roth's spots may be seen in -
  • ➤ Roth's spots may be seen in -
  • ➤ 1. Leukemia
  • ➤ 2. Diabetes
  • ➤ 3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • ➤ 4. Hypertensive retinopathy
  • ➤ 5. HIV retinopathy
  • ➤ 6. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • ➤ 7. Anemia
  • ➤ 8. Pre-eclampsia
  • ➤ 9. Anoxi

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below: NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cover-uncover test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cover-uncover test is a simple and effective method to detect and diagnose latent and manifest deviations of the eyes by observing the movement of the uncovered eye during fixation on a target.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer is suspected? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sebaceous cell carcinoma is a malignancy of the sebaceous glands, which can present as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Chalazion is an inflammation of the meibomian glands , which are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids.
  • • meibomian glands
  • • While chalazion is typically a benign condition, its recurrence, particularly in elderly patients, can be indicative of underlying sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • • This carcinoma is notorious for masquerading as benign eyelid lesions, thus a history of recurrent chalazion warrants further investigation to rule out this malignancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma : This is the second most common type of eyelid cancer, but it does not typically present as recurrent chalazion. It more often presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcerative lesion.
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma
  • • second most common
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma : This is the most common eyelid cancer but usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma
  • • most common eyelid cancer
  • • Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma : This vascular tumor is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV/AIDS. It typically presents as red or purple macules, plaques, or nodules, not as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, especially in elderly patients, as this malignancy can mimic benign eyelid lesions.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: On retinal examination of a hypertensive patient, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema were seen. Which grade of hypertensive retinopathy will it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Grade 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:
  • ➤ Keith-Wagener-Barker Classification:

questions.text: 2 hours after waking up from general anesthesia, a patient complained of eye ache and difficulty in vision. The first line of management must be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mannitol + Atropine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line management of malignant glaucoma involves using Mannitol to reduce vitreous volume and IOP, combined with cycloplegics like Atropine to posteriorly rotate the ciliary body and lens-iris diaphragm.

questions.text: Oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of which of the following cranial nerves? (INICET NOV 2022) 1. III 2. IV 3. VI 4. VIII 5. VII
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oculocephalic reflex assesses the integrity of cranial nerves III (oculomotor), VI (abducens), and VIII (vestibulocochlear), which are crucial for coordinated eye movements in response to head motion.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe eye pain, redness, and thick purulent discharge. The symptoms started gradually over 2 days after swimming in a contaminated pool while wearing contact lenses. On examination, there is a central corneal infiltrate with satellite lesions and hypopyon. Which organism is the most likely causative agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas keratitis is a sight-threatening emergency characterized by rapid progression, central corneal infiltrate with satellite lesions, and hypopyon, commonly occurring in contact lens wearers exposed to contaminated water

questions.text: Oculus Dexter refers to: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Right Eye

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • "Oculus Dexter" (OD) is a term used in ophthalmology to refer to the right eye. The terminology comes from Latin, where "Oculus" means "eye" and "Dexter" means "right." This is a common notation used in medical records and prescriptions related to eye care.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Left Eye (Oculus Sinister): Referred to as "OS" in medical terminology.
  • • Option A. Left Eye (Oculus Sinister):
  • • Option C. Both Eyes (Oculus Uterque): Referred to as "OU" in medical terminology.
  • • Option C. Both Eyes (Oculus Uterque):
  • • Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as OD clearly refers to the right eye.
  • • Option D. None of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Oculus Dexter" (OD) refers to the right eye.
